abstract.p: Due to new European standards and requirements for energy performance in non-residential buildings, it is important to explore and quantify the benefits of intelligent (automated) energy-efficient operating systems relative to conventional (manual) systems. This paper explores the energy performance of an automated lighting control system under realistic conditions in two groups of lecture rooms that have the same shape, dimensions and exposure. The results demonstrate that the use of automated systems for electric lighting control can improve the energy performance of the system between 40% and 65% depending on the complexity of the system and the parameters under control.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: An early definition of sustainable development was formulated in 1987 by the World Commission on Environment and Development (WCED).1 The importance of environmental issues became a key aspect of political and scientific debates around the world from that moment.2 In this context, the built environment plays an important role: The residential and commercial sectors account for more than 40% of end energy consumption in the European Community and are thus responsible for an important part of carbon dioxide emissions.3 According to the IEA (International Energy Agency), electricity use for lighting ranges from 5% (Belgium and Luxembourg) to 15% (Denmark, Japan, and the Netherlands) of the total electrical energy use in industrialised countries. Approximately 50% of lighting energy (531 TWh) in IEA member countries evaluated is used within the service sector (from 39% in Germany and Japan to 61% in the Netherlands).4

Considerable savings could be achieved by application of intelligent control technologies in existing buildings, with acceptable economic implications.5 New European Regulations refer specifically to the use of occupancy and light sensors to control artificial light and to improve the systems’ efficiency.6 Software design tools are intended to help designers with the qualitative and quantitative elements of daylighting design through features that commonly include: Visualisation of the luminous environment of a given daylighting design, prediction of daylight factors in a space lit by diffuse daylight, control of the penetration of the sun’s rays and visualisation of the dynamic behaviour of sunlight.7 In addition, software applications have been developed to predict the energy saving obtainable using automated lighting systems: Specifically the dimming of the artificial light as a function of the natural light levels measured at discrete points.8–13

These simulation tools require lengthy input processes and are too time consuming to be used by architects and designers. As a result, simplified methods have been developed to estimate the saving in electrical energy use for artificial lighting due to the proper use of daylight. However, the parameters typically considered (window area, window type, perimeter area) do not include automated control systems.14

Moreover, energy simulation tools for existing buildings do not necessarily adequately model the actual performance of daylighting systems. The use of reference information instead of measured solar radiation data can cause errors of between 10% and 25%.15 Energy saving potential can be increased up to 27% by proper adjustment of the lighting control system.16 Standard sky conditions considered in many simulation programs are often far from the real data (overestimated up to 30% and underestimated up to 60%17). The main causes of prediction errors are temporal problems, outdoor illuminance and sky luminance distribution simulation, fenestration features, operation, indoor illuminance level expected, human factors and lighting control results.15

These last two factors show a high variability and significantly influence the final energy saving amount expected from the operation of automated control systems. For this reason, the international scientific community carried out several studies in order to monitor and analyse users’ interactions with building control systems and devices.18–20 The computational modelling of occupants’ control-oriented actions in building performance simulation applications can be significantly improved when based on such empirical information as user behaviour21 and real use conditions. In this way it is possible to collect data about both building users’ interactions with building control systems and device efficiency in order to develop a stochastic model for predicting lighting energy consumption.

For this reason, it is important to explore and quantify the benefits of energy efficient automated control systems compared with a conventional (manual) operation system via realistic case studies. The energy saving potential of automated lighting scenarios should be monitored in real use conditions and not just in controlled laboratory environments in order to reliably document the energy efficiency of automated control systems.22 A number of studies have been conducted in this field23,24 where the monitored scenarios are compared with assumed conditions and not actually monitored ones.

sec.title: 1.1 Aim of the paper
sec.p: This paper deals with an elaboration of an innovative design tool for lighting systems. Specifically, a methodological approach for the energy efficiency evaluation under different scenarios is presented. A comparison has been made between automated lighting operation on the one side and conventional operation scenarios on the other side of a building.

The goals of the data analysis presented in this paper are:
To calculate the percentage energy saving potential for various applications of building automation systems used for lighting control.
To monitor users’ behaviour in lecture halls with the traditional lighting system and to quantify the amount of energy use constituting an improper use of electric light.
To analyse the performance of the automated systems, in order to improve their efficiency in different scenarios.

The final objective in this research is to compare the performance of lighting systems operated manually and lighting systems operated automatically in terms of energy efficiency and the visual comfort maintained.

sec.title: 2. Method
sec.p: The analysis of environmental conditions is conducted in two groups of spaces, namely lecture rooms at the Faculty of Engineering of the University of Trento – Italy, with the same shape, dimensions, and orientation.

The geometrical parameters checked in order to guarantee the comparability of the spaces are:
Geometric base case (orientation, dimension – area and perimeter, etc.).
Materials for walls, ceiling(s) and floor(s).
Openings (windows, roof lights) and their positions.
Outside obstructions for the windows.
Luminaires.
In this research the manual lighting system is assumed to be operated by switching the lights on/off. The automatic operating scenarios are defined as follows:

list-item.p: Occupancy detection and minimum illuminance control, as primary condition to switch on the lighting system (if Em > Ethreshold then switch off, where Em = mean illuminance coming from daylight).
Dimming regulation of the artificial light as a function of the natural light level detected at discrete points, as the second automation level.

Occupancy detection by zones (the space has been divided into discrete parts, each one detected by a presence sensor) and minimum illuminance control as primary condition to switch on the lighting system (if Em > Ethreshold then switch off).
Dimming regulation of the artificial light in more dimming loops in order to approximate an ideal continuous dimming in the space, as the second automation level.
Use of different and more efficient light sources.

sec.title: 2.1 Energy saving percentage
sec.p: The energy consumption of both automated systems and traditional ones has been recorded in order to use these data to calculate the mean energy use of the traditional class rooms (ML) with the scenarios (SL1, SL2, SL3 levels).

The energy consumption of the i-th room has been recorded in Wh/m2. This data has been divided by a defined operating time interval, so that it has been calculated in terms of W/m2 (Equation (1)). In order to have a continuous profile of energy demand, a system with a significant detection interval has to be used. For this purpose an impulse counter has been interfaced to a static active energy meter.

A detection time interval has to be fixed. The discrete number of Wh accumulated in this time interval has been recorded and displayed by the supervision system as: (1)eci=(1/N∑j=1Neci,jtj)fai where:
eci,j = energy consumption of the i-th room during the j-th time interval, for the observed operating period (W/m2).
j = j-th time interval.
fai = i-th room floor area (m2).
N = number of intervals (day).

The energy consumption for the ML during the j-th interval, expressed in W/m2, has been calculated as: (2)ecML=1/N∑i=1Neci,j where:
eci,j = energy consumption of the i-th room operated by manual system during the j-th time interval (W/m2).
j = j-th time interval.
N = number of rooms operated by the manual system considered.

sec.title: 2.2 Observed occupancy time
sec.p:
Presence is recorded by a numerical variable defined as an integer that assumes the value 1 if occupancy is detected or the value 0 if it is not (absence). Each datum recorded is correlated with the detection time. The time included between two values equal to 1 of the presence variable is the presence interval (Equation (3)), the time included between two values equal to 0 of the presence variable is the absence interval (Equation (4)). (3)pi,j=tj+1-tj if the presence variable value is 1 where:
i = room detected index
j = time interval index
(4)ai,j=tj+1-tj if the presence variable value is 0 and Δta > >Δta,min while ai,j=pi,j where i is the room detected index and j is the time interval index.
The space is monitored by the occupancy sensors after a defined time interval, determined by the accuracy of the measurement and the precision of the device.

These data have to be collected and registered in a databank by the supervision software, calculating a minimum significant absence period Δta,min, defined depending on the space size and the activity typology. This time interval could be smaller than the one implemented in the presence sensor detection program.

The normalisation factor for presence PFi (Equation (5)) has to be calculated for each automated room as the ratio between the arithmetic mean of observed presence (in seconds) in each automated room PA,i (Equation (6)) and the arithmetic mean of observed presence in the traditional rooms considered PT (in seconds) (Equations (7) and (8)). (5)PA,i=1N·∑j=1Npi,j (6)PFi=PA,iPT where:
pi,j = presence seconds in the i-th automated room during the j-th presence time interval
N = number of time intervals into which a day has been divided
(7)PT,i=1N·∑j=1Npi,j where:
pi,j = presence seconds in the i-th traditional room during the j-th presence time interval
N = number of time intervals into which a day has been divided
(8)PT=1N·∑i=1NPT,i where:
N = number of rooms operated manually under monitoring.

sec.title: 2.3 Outside illuminance
sec.p: Each room monitored has a different occupancy time related to the time table of the workday. In order to compare the same outside conditions it is necessary to check and compare the outside illumination conditions during the occupancy period.

For this reason a normalisation factor IFi (Equation (9)) has been introduced. It is calculated as the ratio between the arithmetic mean of the outside illuminance during the work period in each automated room IAi (Equation (10)) and the arithmetic mean calculated for the manually operated rooms IT (Equation (11)). (9)IFi=IA,iIT (10)IA,i=1N·∑j=1Nii,j where:
ii,j = outside illuminance for the i-th automated room during the j-th time interval.
N = numbers of time intervals into which a day has been divided.
(11)IT=1N·∑i=1NIT,i where:
N = number of rooms operated manually under monitoring.

The outside illumination in lux is monitored and recorded by a numerical variable defined as an integer. Each datum recorded is correlated with the detection time. The detection interval is implemented in the weather device program depending on the technical characteristic of the instrument and on the climatic conditions of the monitored site.

sec.title: 2.4 Indoor illuminance values
sec.p: The intelligent light system is regulated and dimmed by means of light detectors and dimming actuators in order to guarantee a minimum illuminance level (in compliance with the existing European standard25). Nevertheless, in traditional rooms build before 2004, the minimum illuminance could be lower, in compliance with the previous standard.26 Note that in this paper the illuminance is the sum of daylight and electric light unless specified otherwise.

In order to evaluate different levels of lighting system performance, as a function of the illuminance maintained on the task area, the indoor illuminance factor ii has been introduced (Equation (12)). This factor is calculated as the weighted mean between the illuminance detected Ei,j and the minimum illuminance Emin: (12)ii=1-(1N·∑j=1NEmin-Ei,jEmin) where:
Ei,j = inside illuminance in the i-th traditional room during the j-th time interval.
N = number of time intervals into which a day has been divided.

sec.title: 2.5 Calculation of the energy saving for each scenario
sec.p: Using the normalisation factors explained above, the energy use and the consequent performance of each scenario is defined in conformity with the boundary conditions of the other rooms monitored (Equation (13)). So, in a second step, it will be possible to establish the energy saving percentage for different scenarios in comparison with the ML. (13)SLi=(1N·∑j=1Neci,j)·PFi·IFi·ii With the paired comparison between the operation systems of each scenario, it is possible to define the energy saving percentage for each automation system solution.

sec.title: 2.6 Typical day data analysis
sec.p: In order to understand and model users’ behaviour in traditional classrooms (ML) and to quantify the energy saving potentials of automation systems for lighting control, a typical day data analysis has been carried out. In this way, it is possible to perform an hourly data analysis, instead of a daily overview of the system functions and user interactions. To conduct this statistical analysis, it is necessary to consider the conditions operating in the monitored environment during a defined time interval over the course of the day.

The data monitored by the input devices of the automation system are sent to the bus not regularly, but in an event-based manner (recorded by the supervision system). For this reason, the data for each day analysed has been averaged considering a discrete temporal interval, using a LabView calculation programmed for the research data analysis. In this way the collected results are synchronised and it is possible to relate different factors occurring at the same time in a specific room.

sec.title: 3. Case study
sec.p:
The research has been carried out at the Faculty of Engineering of the University of Trento – Italy. The cross-shaped layout of the building is characterised by two parallel wings, both facing south (Figure 1). The lecture rooms are symmetrical and have the same shape. This configuration allows the comparison between three classrooms in the east wing (2A, 2B, and 2C), operated in a conventional manner (luminaires operated manually by the users), and three classrooms in the west wing (2M, 2N, and 2P), operated automatically and programmed specifically for different scenarios. Figure 1.
Building and luminaire layout (above: in east wing traditional classrooms, in west wing automated classrooms; next page: control circuits distribution and sensor positions).

In the traditional classrooms considered, both teachers and students have the right to control electric lighting (switch on and off) as well as opening windows and shutters, depending on their common needs. (Note that the blinds are also manually operated in the classrooms with automated lighting controls.)

The main geometric parameters describing the classrooms analysed are the following:
2P, 2N, 2B, 2C: 32 seats, length 7 m, width 6.3 m, height 3 m, three windows each 1.4 m width and 2.8 m height.
2M, 2A: 77 seats, length 12.8 m, width 6.3 m, height 3 m, six windows each 1.4 m width and 2.8 m height.

We measured the inside illuminance on the desk using a grid of discrete point (1.5 m x 1.5 m) with no electric lights on and with window blinds retracted during 4 days in the winter season and 4 days in the summer season, considering different sky conditions. We have verified that the difference in the data was small (around 10% close to the windows, less than 5% internally). The measurements were also compared with a simulation model of the rooms performed with Adeline and the results fit the simulation outputs. The installed electric power density and electric light illuminance was also the same in both groups of rooms.

sec.title: 3.1 Lighting system design
sec.p: The technology used to control the lecture halls is a comprehensive, integrated system for home and building automation: the Konnex solution. The KNX standard complies with the regulations EN 50090 (standard containing technical rules from Home and Building Electronic Systems) and allows a remarkable flexibility for the electric system.

The lighting used in lecture room 2M is a fluorescent ceiling luminaire 4x14W T5. In the other rooms the lighting type used is a fluorescent ceiling luminaire 4x18W T8. In the constant light regulation mode, the lights are operated in parallel rows.
In each traditional classroom a presence/light sensor has been installed, but only for monitoring.

The scenarios implemented and monitored in the research case study are defined as follows:
Scenario 1: use of occupancy sensors (the light will be turned off automatically after 15 min of absence) and minimum illuminance control (if Em > 500 lx then switch off). This scenario has been used between September and December in the classroom 2P.
Scenario 2: as scenario 1 plus dimming regulation of the electric light in two rows of dimming loops (Ethreshold = 500 lx, in compliance with existing standard25). This scenario has been applied in the new classroom 2 N for the whole year.
Scenario 3: as scenario 2, but with dimming of the electric light in three rows of dimming loops, switching on divided by zones (the lecture room has been divided into two parts, each one detected by a presence sensor).This scenario has been applied in the new classroom 2M during the whole year.
Scenario 1 bis: as scenario 2, but with dimming of the electric light in three rows of dimming loops. This scenario has been applied in the new classroom 2P between March and June.
It is necessary to specify that in traditional lecture rooms the minimum illuminance should be only 300 lx, in compliance with the old national regulation.26

In the second semester (Spring semester from March to June) the illuminance required has been changed to 300 lx instead of the 500 lx of the first semester. In this way it is possible to verify the effective energy saving percentage for the same performance of the light system.

ML vs. 2P’ = > dimming 1 + 1 + 1 (scenario 2)
2N vs. 2P = > dimming 1 + 2 (scenario 3)

In order to detect and record outside meteorological conditions a weather station has been installed. This device is used primarily for detection of brightness, but can also measure rain, temperature, day/night and wind speeds. It is necessary to select a place for the installation on the building where the wind, rain and sun can be measured uninhibited by obstructions. In particular, the light dome of the cover must not be in a shadow of the building or other external obstructions. In order to observe these installation requirements, the weather station has been installed closed to the roof, on the upper part of the south façade of the university building.

sec.title: 4. Data analysis evaluation
sec.p:
The data recorded and analysed are:
Presence and absence periods (by infrared occupancy sensors in all six classrooms).
Indoor illuminances (by indoor illuminance sensors).
External illuminances (by weather station).
Dimming percentage (by dimming actuators for scenarios involving dimming operations).
Energy use for lighting system (monitored separately for each lecture room by means of 6 dedicated meters).

Monitoring results are stored in a database and structured by the supervision software Gefasoft 7.1.27 For each day, a file is generated with temporally ordered data. Each single message is labelled with its own number by means of a FORTRAN program.28 The different data points have been synchronised using the LabView program.29

sec.p:

sec.title: 5. Discussion
sec.p: There is a difference between the occupancy levels monitored in the traditional classrooms in different winter and summer months. In addition, the occupancy level differs significantly between traditional rooms and those with the automated control scenarios (see for instance scenario 1 in the winter semester – Figure 2). Thus, it was necessary to normalise the energy use values based on the occupancy data so as to properly compare the various scenarios. A normalisation was also performed regarding the outdoor illuminances that significantly change with the period considered, even though in this case the variations of illuminances for different scenarios were no more than 3% to 5% throughout the observation period. The occupancy period differs for each classroom, depending on the lecture schedule. As a consequence, the outdoor illuminance is different during the lecture period.

The indoor illuminance levels in the three traditional classrooms differ from each other and are different in different months (Figure 3). Specifically, at certain periods, early in the morning or late in the evening, the illuminances are rather low. This is due to the fact that users either did not switch on the lights or did not open the shading devices. This fact was considered in the comparison of energy use values taking into account the actually prevailing illuminances. The classrooms have been modelled with the simulation software Adeline3.8 We compared calibrated simulated indoor illuminances (without the electric lighting contribution) with those measured by sensors for cases with the shades open. Simulated values were significantly higher than measured ones (Figure 4). This can be explained by considering the shades’ positions. In fact, the shading system is not always properly used to maximise daylight utilisation.

The energy consumption in traditional classrooms does not always directly correlate with outdoor illuminances. Indeed, the energy consumption during morning and early afternoon in October is higher than in the same period in November even if outside illuminance conditions are more favourable. Nonetheless, the mean energy use over the whole observation period is clearly related to outside illuminance, especially comparing winter and summer mean energy demand (Figure 5).

The monitored energy use patterns in the classrooms with automated lighting control scenarios show a better daylight utilisation. In the winter semester the energy use for scenario 1 is higher than scenario 3, especially during evening classes, since maintaining the minimum illuminance (in scenario 1) requires all luminaires to be switched on. Again we can observe better performance in the summer months for scenario 3 when compared with traditional lecture rooms (Figure 6).

As mentioned earlier, the monitored energy use for the traditional classrooms and the ones with automated lighting control scenarios could not be directly compared, given the differences in occupancy and maintained illuminances. To observe the effect of occupancy, we can consider that the energy consumption of scenario 2 after 18:30 is higher than for ML but, considering the occupancy period as a normalisation factor, the energy demand in ML is higher in the last lesson hours (Figure 7).

To illustrate the effect of the maintained illuminances, Figure 8 shows the monitored energy use for scenario 2 together with normalised curves for maintained illuminances of 300 lx and 500 lx. The effect of normalisation is understandably more significant in the evening and early morning hours, especially in the winter semester when compared to the summer one.

Table 2 shows the energy saving in different winter semester months for the three scenarios calculated as absolute values and, additionally, normalised for the following factors: presence, outdoor illuminance, and inside illuminace. The effect of the normalisation factors is significant in the energy saving calculation. For instance, in October the application of the normalisation factors calculated for scenario 3 increases the energy saving from 53.45% to 76.32%. The more significant standardisation factor is indoor illuminance factor: Normalising by inside illuminance, the saving amount can increase by 15.07%.

The use of automation techniques achieves a significant energy saving. The overall energy use comparison between traditional and automated classrooms shows that, depending on the observation month,
Scenario 1 requires 39% to 49% less energy for electric lighting.
Scenario 2 consumes 40% to 85% less electrical energy monthly for lighting.
Scenario 3 needs 50% to 85% less electrical energy for lighting.

Comparing winter and summer trends, the mean energy saving for scenario 3 is above the 65% for the whole year. Checking the difference between scenario 2 and 3 in the summer semester, there is not any significant improvement in system efficiency. This means that dividing the lecture room into two separate spatial zones (front and back) with dedicated occupancy sensors does not increase efficiency.

The mean difference between the winter and summer semester performances is mainly significant for the scenario 2: Indeed the energy saving percentage for this scenario decreases from the 75% in the winter semester to the 55% in the summer semester.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: The results of the research demonstrate that the use of automated systems for controlling electric lighting can yield considerable energy savings, roughly between 40% and 65% depending on the complexity of the system and the parameters under control.
Moreover, it was possible to define new automated lighting scenarios and to investigate their potential (evaluated using standardisation techniques) for the specific case study analysed.

Considering the whole observation period, the energy saving percentage of the automated control as compared with the traditional classroom, was:
40%, with all three rows of luminaires switched on when occupancy is detected and the room illuminance (measured in the middle of the room) is below a predefined minimum level (scenario 1 – winter semester).
65%, with three rows of luminaires switched on when occupancy is detected and dimmed (in two separately controlled circuits) so as to provide predefined minimum illuminances, measured at two points in the room, each corresponding to a circuit (scenario 2). This lighting system has a better performance in winter than in the summer.
65%, with three rows of luminaires switched on when occupancy is detected and dimmed (in three separately controlled circuits) so as to provide predefined minimum illuminances (measured at three points in the room, each corresponding to a circuit – scenario 3).
There are no significant differences in the results if the lecture room is controlled in terms of two separate spatial zones (front and back) with dedicated occupancy sensors.

It is important to notice that disability and discomfort glare influence this trend, because an improper use of the shading system often causes the unnecessary use of the electric lighting. Moreover, visual comfort is not always guaranteed. In fact, the minimum illuminance maintained in the traditional classrooms is low, especially in the winter semester in the early morning and late in the afternoon. Thus, the automated control system used for this research could be further improved by incorporating shading control.
